result.execSummary:
The defendant Jacob G Drover was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct - County Ordinance. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Fine to be paid by 10-3-2016 or penalty of 2 days jail for non-payment.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jacob G Drover

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt:
Melissa Zilavy appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Attorney Joseph James Dorlack in court.   
Defendant Jacob G Drover did not appear. 
Court waives the defendant's appearance.

State moves to amend count 2 to a county ordinance of DC.
Defense has no objections.

Atty. Dorlack enters a plea of No Contest to the amended charge on behalf of his client.
Court finds the defendant Guilty of the amended charge.
Count 1 is dismissed as a read in.

Court orders the following:
Fine:  $210.80
To be paid in full by:  10/03/16.
Alternate:  2 Days in the Waukesha County Jail.
Plea/sentencing hearing on May 26, 2016 at 02:45 pm.
